content.title: Penetrating Atherosclerotic Ulcer (PAU)
content.definition: Ulceration of an atherosclerotic plaque that penetrates through the internal elastic lamina into the aortic media, causing localized intramural hematoma and potentially progressing to pseudoaneurysm, dissection, or rupture. Part of the acute aortic syndrome spectrum.

key_concepts.description: Atherosclerotic plaque ulcerates → penetrates internal elastic lamina → exposes media → local hemorrhage into media → weakened wall may lead to pseudoaneurysm, dissection, or rupture
Older patients (mean age 70s) with extensive atherosclerosis; more common in descending thoracic aorta; less common in ascending aorta (which has less atherosclerosis)
May be asymptomatic (incidental); symptomatic: acute chest/back pain similar to dissection; or chronic symptoms from aneurysmal degeneration
Most common in mid-to-distal descending thoracic aorta; also abdominal aorta; rare in ascending aorta (atherosclerosis less common there)
CT: focal contrast-filled outpouching extending beyond expected lumen contour; associated intramural hematoma; irregular atherosclerotic aorta
PAU: localized, elderly, atherosclerotic, descending aorta; Dissection: extensive, younger, connective tissue disease, ascending common. Can coexist
Variable: some remain stable; may progress to pseudoaneurysm, aneurysm, or rupture; unpredictable course; larger and symptomatic PAU higher risk
Medical management with BP control and surveillance imaging for small, stable PAU; threshold for intervention lower than simple atherosclerotic aneurysm
TEVAR preferred for descending thoracic PAU (good results, less invasive); open repair for ascending (rare) or TEVAR landing zone issues
Higher than IMH; symptomatic PAU or PAU >20mm depth/diameter have significant rupture risk; size thresholds lower than simple aneurysm

definition.@value: Ulceration of an atherosclerotic plaque that penetrates the aortic media, causing intramural hematoma with risk of pseudoaneurysm, dissection, or rupture

learning_objectives: Define penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer and its mechanism
Recognize CT features (focal outpouching, associated IMH)
Understand the variable and unpredictable natural history
Know that TEVAR is preferred treatment for symptomatic descending PAU
clinical_pearls: PAU = atherosclerotic ulcer eroding into media
Older patient with atherosclerosis (unlike typical dissection patient)
Most common in descending thoracic aorta
Focal outpouching with associated intramural hematoma on CT
TEVAR is excellent treatment for descending PAU
Higher rupture risk than IMH - lower threshold for intervention
common_mistakes: Confusing with simple atherosclerotic ulcer (PAU penetrates media)
Not recognizing as acute aortic syndrome
